newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish security head fired over egg-throw scandal.
newsitem.headline: Polish security head fired over egg-throw scandal.

text.p: Poland's interior minister on Wednesday fired the chief of the government agency protecting state officials after it failed to stop four Poles from flinging eggs at President Aleksander Kwasniewski in Paris.
Three of the Poles appeared in court in Paris, where two of them were given suspended prison terms and the third was aquitted.

Minister Leszek Miller said he had sacked General Miroslaw Gawor because he could not excuse mistakes by the agency, called the Government Protection Office (BOR), especially before a visit of Pope John Paul II starting on May 31.
"BOR's mistakes, especially before the Pope's visit, cannot be tolerated," Miller told reporters. He said he appointed BOR's deputy head Colonel Henryk Sobczyk as its new chief.
The rightists targeted Kwasniewski, a former communist turned social democrat, and his wife Jolanta with eggs last Sunday as they entered a Champs Elysees theatre in Paris.
The projectiles missed Kwasniewski, who had come to Paris to see President Jacques Chirac.
But Polish media reported that his wife and one of his aides were hit and were planning law suits against their attackers, who were detained by police.
Lukasz Kazmierczak, and Woytek Wybranowski, both 23, were sentenced to three months suspended prison terms each in Paris.
They were also ordered to pay yet-to-be-determined damages to the aide who was hit while a third accused, Piotr Grzmeski, 25, was found not guilty. No mention was made of a fourth man.
The public prosecutor had asked for six-month suspended sentences against the trio, who were accused of premeditated assault. They said their action was "a political joke".

The Polish Foreign Ministry on Tuesday sent a note to France, which was officially responsible for Kwasniewski's security in Paris, urging it to step up protection measures for visiting officials to avoid similar events in the future.
Kwasniewski's attackers, who travelled to Paris precisely to hurl eggs at the president, come from two small, virtually unknown rightist groups.

They and other bigger organisations, rooted in the former opposition to the communist system, say Kwasniewski and his political allies from the co-ruling ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance should be disqualified from politics because of their involvement in the old regime before 1989.
Kwasniewski was elected in 1995. His party emerged victorious from parliamentary elections two years earlier.
